title: Do the AI robots know that they exist in this world? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, AI sometimes does know that it exists. If we consider a recommender system for instance, it is aware that people have deep thoughts that they can’t describe with their limited vocabulary. Early recommender systems tried to predict what would be purchased in the future, based on the user’s past purchases. Once an accurate model was developed, it would be deployed, then reviewed later. The thing was, the training data was biased by the previous “recommender system” − maybe just an alphabetic list that biased people into choosing movies at the start of the alphabet. With a constant feedback loop and more reliance on machine learning, modern recommender systems now take an approach that can better be described as producing the most clicks or purchases of the items shown to the users. The algorithm also takes into account the other items that were shown, but not purchased. Let’s say for instance that we show the user a box of tissues, then we show them some bouquets; a coffin; and a photo frame with a sample picture that looks like an old woman. The AI learns that it can generate sales of tissues out of thin air. It’s no longer just predicting what was going to happen anyway; it’s taking an active involvement in the process. It can further refine its process by learning what triggers different users. A further scenario to consider is recommendations sent by email − the more initiative shown by a recommender system, the more sentient we should regard it to be. When we’re discussing anthropomorphised behaviour, a useful anecdote is a story of Isaac Asimov (I forget which one sorry) where some robots are meant to send various information back to the home planet, which is carefully aligned in the radio telescope. The thing is, they don’t think that they’re sending back weather reports; they think that they’re paying worship to some sort of orb god in the distance. The engineers consider rewriting the responsible code, but take the beloved attitude “if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it”.

Like humans, does the AI robots know that they exist in this world? Bloggers and journalists hungry for eyeballs have always used hype to grab you by those balls and get your attention. The more readers, the more they can charge for ads. “AI” is now pretty much just the word for “computer programs.” If you believe the ads and other blarney, everything with a chip is “intelligent.” It isn’t. Nothing fundamental has changed. Programmers have learned some tricks that make software better at pattern recognition, and the hardware has become cheaper and faster so those complex programs can be run on little computers like “smartphones.” That’s great, I use it, I love it, but it disgusts me that it’s packaged and sold as “Artificial Intelligence.” When folks realize it’s nothing of the sort, the usual disappointment and cynicism will set in. The word “intelligence” suggests self-awareness. In fact it suggests more. Rabbits and cows are self-aware, but most of us don’t find them “intelligent.” So “Artificial Intelligence” must mean that Siri and Cortana and Google Now are smart, smarter than cows and rabbits, just a step away from having human feelings and making plans and hatching plots, right? Wrong. In the usual sense of “intelligence,” “AI robots” are exactly as smart as a bicycle or a hammer. Why does this bother me so much? Because for fifty years I’ve been annoying my few friends with visions of a future in which evolution by natural selection will segue into the intelligent design (by people) of our successors in the form of truly intelligent, self-aware “machines” — always given that animals are machines, and so are computer programs. I have no idea what physical form “artificial intelligence” will take. But it isn’t coming next year or in this century. The problems are too many and too difficult. All of which is a long-winded way of answering your question with a firm No.

“AI robots” are nothing more than computers running software. Does your computer “know” that it exists? Neither does the “smartest” AI ever written so far - it’s just software that’s very well-designed by … a human being. Asimov’s “positronic brains” are fiction, not reality - and never will be. Oh, we might some day develop something that can simulate “thinking” and “knowing”, but a machine will always be just a machine. A “thinking, knowing machine” is always going to be fiction.

Not at this time. The question of what consciousness is, is a long way from being answered in my opinion. We could program a robot or AI to ask and answer questions as if it were conscious, but would that be the same as what a human does? How self-conscious are most people? For an interesting experiment, have someone video you while you do normal things. Then play it back five days in a row.

Nope, certainly not yet, what you’re suggesting is self-awareness. AI and robots are at least a decade away from self-awareness (and that’s if Ray Kurzweil is 100% correct and his “Law of Accelerating Returns” continues… that suggests that one of the new RAM replacement memory technologies should be working this year…I’ll let you know in 11 months if it is).

Awareness resides in the human brain. AI can simulate but not duplicate the human brain, which make very well be the most complex entity known to humans. It is embedded in our biological being and is not so much a thing as it is a process. Duplicating it in non-biologic systems is not possible. Simulate, yes; duplicate, no.
